G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201321.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Lynn District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit and all events giving rise to this claim occurred in Essex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Defendant resides or has a usual place of business in this county and the acts complained of occurred here.

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 51.proposition: The building comprised multiple apartment units, and Defendant had the legal duty to maintain common areas and safety equipment, including hallway smoke detectors, pursuant to G.L. c. 143, §§ 3, 51, and the Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code (527 C.M.R. 1.00 et seq.).

527 C.M.R. 1.00 et seq..proposition: The building comprised multiple apartment units, and Defendant had the legal duty to maintain common areas and safety equipment, including hallway smoke detectors, pursuant to G.L. c. 143, §§ 3, 51, and the Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code (527 C.M.R. 1.00 et seq.).

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26A, 26F.proposition: Defendant’s duty arose under both common law and statutory obligations, including: - G.L. c. 148, §§ 26A, 26F (mandating operable smoke detectors in residential buildings);

780 C.M.R. \u00a7 907.2.11 et seq..proposition: Defendant’s duty arose under both common law and statutory obligations, including: - State Building Code, 780 C.M.R. § 907.2.11 et seq. and 527 C.M.R. 1.00 (defining maintenance obligations for detectors).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff was not comparatively negligent and acted with due care under the circumstances. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff seeks all damages available under law, including compensatory damages, costs, interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and such other relief as the Court deems just and proper.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain safe and habitable premises, including proper maintenance of fire safety devices such as smoke detectors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: This excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard concerns the abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and briefly questions the treatment of trespassers. It addresses the general standard of care owed by occupiers of land to persons on the premises, not a specific duty to maintain safe and habitable premises or fire safety devices such as smoke detectors. Nothing in the provided text discusses habitability standards or fire protection systems, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain safe and habitable premises, including proper maintenance of fire safety devices such as smoke detectors.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The court expressly abandons the old common‑law limitations and holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to unreasonable risk of harm, including on demised premises. It grounds this duty both in general negligence principles and in statutes requiring landlords to correct unsafe conditions for “any person rightfully on the premises,” which encompasses maintaining the safety of the premises for tenants and their guests. Although the specific facts involve a porch railing rather than smoke detectors, the principle clearly extends to reasonable care in maintaining safety features on the premises, including fire‑safety devices.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk… Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well… Thus, the landlord is liable in negligence for defects of which he has notice, even though the defect occurs on the rented premises.”

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.proposition: This conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law. See Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (1994) (landlord liable for failure to remedy dangerous condition); Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 416 Mass. 433 (1993) (duty exists where harm is foreseeable); Granger v. Arias, 307 Mass. 116 (1940) (negligent maintenance creates liability).
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Whittaker as authority that the conduct at issue constitutes negligence and that the landlord is liable for failure to remedy a dangerous condition. In Whittaker, however, the Supreme Judicial Court held the opposite: it concluded that the landlord had no duty to protect the plaintiff from the criminal assault because the attack was not reasonably foreseeable, vacated the verdict, and ordered judgment for the defendant. While the case recognizes in general that commercial landlords have a duty to protect against reasonably foreseeable criminal acts, its holding is that no negligence existed on the facts presented.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The attack on the plaintiff was not reasonably foreseeable. There was no evidence that the landlord knew or reasonably should have known that a physical attack might occur in the building. … Here the defendant had no duty to the plaintiff to provide protection against a not reasonably foreseeable act of violence against her. … The verdict is vacated. The judgment is reversed, and the case is remanded for the entry of judgment for the defendant.”

Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 41.raw_text: Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 416 Mass. 433 (1993)
Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 41.proposition: This conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law. See Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (1994) (landlord liable for failure to remedy dangerous condition); Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 416 Mass. 433 (1993) (duty exists where harm is foreseeable); Granger v. Arias, 307 Mass. 116 (1940) (negligent maintenance creates liability).
Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 41.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co.; it is a criminal appeal (Commonwealth v. LaPlante) concerning murder convictions, search and seizure issues, evidentiary rulings, and insanity instructions. It does not address negligence, duties arising from foreseeability of harm, landlord liability, or premises liability under Massachusetts law. Therefore, this case, as excerpted, does not support the proposition that a negligence duty exists where harm is foreseeable.
Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 41.relevant_excerpt:
The defendant asserts that the “bizarre nature of these killings together with the events following their commission were sufficient to create ... a reasonable doubt as to [the defendant’s] criminal responsibility.” According to the defendant, the Commonwealth’s evidence, if believed, required that the instruction be given. We do not agree.

... On this record, there was no evidence which would trigger the need for an instruction on criminal responsibility.

Granger v. Arias, 307 Mass. 116 (1940).proposition: This conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law. See Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (1994) (landlord liable for failure to remedy dangerous condition); Limoncelli v. New York Life Ins. Co., 416 Mass. 433 (1993) (duty exists where harm is foreseeable); Granger v. Arias, 307 Mass. 116 (1940) (negligent maintenance creates liability).
Granger v. Arias, 307 Mass. 116 (1940).case_name: U. S. B. & M. Liquidation Corp. v. Hilton
Granger v. Arias, 307 Mass. 116 (1940).support_reasoning: Granger v. Arias is a conflicts/mortgage-remedies case about the applicability of New York mortgage moratorium statutes to an action on a bond in Massachusetts. It does not discuss negligence, duties of care, maintenance of property, or landlord liability. Citing this case for the proposition that “negligent maintenance creates liability” under Massachusetts law is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s holding or reasoning.
Granger v. Arias, 307 Mass. 116 (1940).relevant_excerpt: This is an action against a defendant described in the writ as of Springfield in this Commonwealth to recover a balance of principal and interest due on a bond executed in the State of New York on November 2, 1931, whereby the defendant covenanted to pay the sum of the bond to the obligee, its successors or assigns, in monthly instalments of principal and interest and to pay the unpaid balance of principal on November 2, 1936. The plaintiff is the present holder of the bond.

LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.raw_text: LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 463 Mass. 316 (2012)
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that failure to maintain a functioning smoke detector created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of serious injury or death to tenants. See LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 463 Mass. 316 (2012) (foreseeability central to negligence).
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.case_name: LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.support_reasoning: The case involves an electrician’s electrocution from inadequately labeled high-voltage switchgear, not a landlord’s failure to maintain smoke detectors for tenants. While the opinion discusses foreseeability in the context of negligence arising from contractual duties and obvious safety risks, it does not address smoke detectors, landlord–tenant duties, or the specific proposition that a defendant knew or should have known that failing to maintain a smoke detector created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of serious injury or death to tenants. Citing this case for that specific smoke-detector foreseeability proposition is therefore inaccurate, though it is generally relevant for the broader idea that foreseeability of harm is key in negligence.
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.relevant_excerpt: “Because the evidence in the summary judgment record is sufficient to support a finding that LeBlanc’s death was caused by the professional negligence of the Design Team based on their failure to report known deficiencies to Hilton that posed a serious safety risk to anyone who operated the switchgear, the judge erred in granting summary judgment to the Design Team on the cross claims for contribution brought by Hilton and Broadway.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Plaintiff justifiably relied on Defendant’s assurances that it would repair the defective smoke detector and thus suffered harm when Defendant failed to act. See Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983) (duty to take reasonable measures for safety).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt (a dissent) concerns proximate cause and campus security measures, not reliance on assurances about repairing a smoke detector or harm resulting from a failure to repair. Mullins v. Pine Manor College is about a college’s duty to take reasonable measures to protect students from criminal acts, not about justifiable reliance or negligent repair of safety equipment. The proposition attributes a reliance-and-undertaking theory that does not appear in, or follow from, the reasoning shown here.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, including smoke inhalation, lost wages, medical expenses, and property damage. See Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978) (proximate cause defined as foreseeable consequence of negligent act).
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses proximate cause in terms of foreseeability of harm resulting from the defendant’s negligence, citing and applying the Lane v. Atlantic Works formulation. While the case facts involve a foot injury from a forklift rather than smoke inhalation, lost wages, or property damage, the legal principle articulated—that a defendant remains liable where the intervening act and resulting injury are reasonably foreseeable—supports the proposition’s use of Jesionek for the definition of proximate cause as a foreseeable consequence of a negligent act.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated, not in the number of subsequent events and agencies which might arise.’ … Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Alholm v. Wareham, 371 Mass. 621 (1976).proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has suffered economic and non-economic damages, including but not limited to medical costs, loss of wages, property loss, and physical pain and emotional distress. See Alholm v. Wareham, 371 Mass. 621 (1976) (damages recoverable for physical injury and emotional distress resulting from negligence).
Alholm v. Wareham, 371 Mass. 621 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses negligence, causation, and municipal/public nuisance liability in the context of a multicar accident, but it does not analyze the categories or scope of recoverable damages, nor does it mention emotional distress or distinguish between economic and non-economic damages. The case is about whether defendants are liable at all, not about what types of damages are recoverable once negligence is established. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that damages are recoverable for physical injury and emotional distress resulting from negligence.
